content.description:
This is a neat line on a unique feature that has a long history of climbing (and other shenanigans). The rock quality wasn't the best originally but we did our best to clean it up, and now it's a pretty worthwhile line.

Climb the southeast arete past 3 bolts and gear to an excellent belay at the top (bolt anchor back from the edge a bit). Step back out to the perfect belay seat at the top and enjoy the view.
content.location: Start from a the ledge just right of the easy chimney on the south side -- See picture.

content.description:
This was probably the first technical/modern ascent of the Camel in recent years, and is tallest line. Full disclaimer: I started up this thing years ago but bailed due to rock quality and haven't been back on it since. However, it does follow a nice natural line and looks like it could be improved greatly with a little clean-up effort.

Start down the hill on the north side.

P-1 Climb the obvious left facing corner up and left past loose rock and into some pockets. Continue up past a 10 crux move and to a gear belay in a shallow alcove/ledge (I believe).

P-2 Climb diagonally up and right around a roof feature, continuing diagonaling up and right to top out somewhere in the vicinity of the chimney separates the "head" of the Camel with the "body".
content.location: North side of the pinnacle. Get there by walking around down and (skier's) right of the SE arete. It's a little bushy but surprisingly easy to reach the base of the route ~ couple minutes.

content.description:
While there is some hollow rock on this climb (seems to be chocked in pretty well), this is a good route for the Camel. A slightly easier and better version of the original East Face route with a classic Linville Gorge finish out the steep juggy wall.

Climb the East face to the block and bolt 2. Move around the left side and up the right to follow the right facing corner. Climb past a few bolts and gear to a steep finish on an arete at the last bolt. Move left onto the arete and finish on jugs to easy terrain leading to summit.
content.protection: Standard rack up to a #3 camelot
content.location: East face -- see picture topo to Camel

content.description:
A fun route that is shady in the afternoon.

Climb up the easy face past some cams to a bolt. Move up and left around block and follow the left-hand line up funky sidepulls to a stance under a roof. Small/med wires protect the move to a bolt above roof. Pull the awkward roof to another roof and get a finger size cam. Move right and to jugs, the follow easy terrain to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack up to #3 or #4 camelot
content.location: East face. Start from a narrow vegetated ledge. See generic picture topo of the Camel.

content.description:
The main trade route to access the top of the camel. Quite an old route. Has old bolts.

If you have info on this route let me know i know nothing of its history, it should see more traffic for how classic it is.

This route begins right where the col or saddle meets the rock and climbs the lower spire. You can lead it with small to medium size cams and rap from a tree on the top of the lower spire. If you are willing to mak a leap to the second taller spire you can top rope some of the harder climbs. Lot's of briars in the saddle.

The climb out below the rappel tree requires you to make a move from an old bolt before you can get good protection. Falling there would not be advisable, but it is fairly moderate at 5.6 or so. Not 5.4 as stated in theold guide book. Leave a rope fixed in case the weather turns bad so you can jug up the face if necessary.

It should be noted that there have been lots of rattle snake sitings in this area during the summer so late fall or winter may be the best time to climb there.
content.protection: Bring gear to back up bolts no anchor
content.location: After rapping into the camel area with NC wall at your back head  to the left and down a little to the south east face of the pillar to a somewhat obvious blocky corner follow this up and over to the west side of the buttress then to the top clipping several old bolts as you go.

content.description: The in/out route to access the camel area it is basically where the trail ends, at one time this was bolted, bolts were called “old” in the thomas kelly guide to NC. So they are 30 years old+ bring stuff to back them up. Route wanders up the easiest path on this face, two bolt anchor has no hangers but can be found at head level slightly hidden, cams .75, 1, & 3 can be placed above.  Use the largest pine tree to rap in(it is climbers left of the route) may want to leave a fixed line if the climb is wet or just for ease of access.
content.protection: Very old bolts and placements to back them up
content.location: From TR parking take MST through the chimnies turn right to go down to camel and apricot buttress, keep right at any splits and head for the camel trail dead ends near the top of this climb.
